sourceDesc.p: This is the feature file for the existential particle.

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Speakers from the same tribe in Mash Had, who coexist with ḥaḍar, show only fī
Negated form ma bīš. In this location speakers from the Lhēb tribe coexist with ḥaḍar. Speakers from the same tribe in Tuba Zangariyya show only bū
According to the source, less common than būwa
According to the source, less common than būwa
According to the source, less common than būwa
According to the source, less common than būwa
According to the source, less common than būwa
The author reports būh and buh reflexes for Qaṣīm, source:internet
the affermative form of the existential is not mentioned, the authors only give the negative form, so the base form was simply deducted
Information deduced from an example, not explicitly stated in the source.
Elicited from the example of the negative form mā-fī-š
Other areas show bih and bīh

This reflex is taken from the map in the Wortatlas der Arabischen Dialekte IV, in the chapter Existential Ausdrücke. The reflex closer to Mecca has been chosen, but this might not be indicative of all existential particles in the entire Hijazi region

This reflex is taken from the map in the Wortatlas der Arabischen Dialekte IV, in the chapter Existential Ausdrücke. The reflex closer to Mecca has been chosen, but this might not be indicative of all existential particles in the entire Hijazi region
hast is not as frequent in Kuwait as it is in Bahrain
refers to the near deixis: there is here
refers to the far deixis: there is there
f.: kāyna, Pl.: kāynin, also found as kān
f.: kāyna, Pl.: kāynin, also found as kān
f.: kāyna, Pl.: kāynin, also found as kān
it is now sometimes replaced by the koiné form fī
